document_title: Bladder stones: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
Bladder stones are hard mineral masses that form in the bladder. They develop when minerals in urine concentrate, crystallize and form stones. This often happens when you have difficulty expelling urine. (first)
Bladder stones occur more often in men than in women. Stones formed in the bladder are often large in size due to long-term accumulation of stone residue from urine in the bladder.
In addition, bladder stones are kidney stones that move down the ureter and fall into the bladder. Small bladder stones can pass out easily during urination. Stones larger than 8mm often get stuck in the bladder neck or urethra (the tube that carries urine out) causing painful urination, weak urine flow or acute urinary retention.
subsection_title: soi bang quang.json. What are bladder stones?

Stones larger than 8mm often get stuck in the bladder neck or urethra (the tube that carries urine out) causing painful urination, weak urine flow or acute urinary retention.
